displayed_text: Patient: Oh, shoot. Oh, God. Doctor: But that’s a lot of travelling, man. Family Member: It’s very interesting. Patient: Oh, my goodness. Whew. That plane ride was a trip. Family Member: We was, uh, kind of like laughing come down here to Baltimore. We were like, Baltimore’s not too far from South Africa with the living conditions. You know? Patient: With how some of these people live. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: I’m like, wow. Patient: My, gosh. We was in Langa, and then Langa- Doctor: So did, was that part of the tour to see that or that was just you could not see that in just where you were going? Patient: Everything was part of the tour. Yeah. Family Member: Um hum. It’s all included. Patient: Everything is, and then you have some passages-

Healthcare Professional: Um um well let me see. (Laughing) Doctor: Sometimes we see your blood numbers for your liver and how they function, sometimes that gets a little bit screwed up. Healthcare Professional: Um hum. Doctor: You don’t feel bad from that but some things we have to monitor. We always say anything with pills can affect your, your, you know your stomach and your bowels. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Doc -so that’s possible. You could get diarrhea or constipation – Healthcare Professional: Um hum. Doctor: - depending on. And then um in point six percent of people you could get a seizure. I point that out out of all the list because that’s to me the most scary - Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: - if it were me. But you know point six is less – Family Member: Right. Doctor: - than one as in we give this stuff all the time and people, knock on wood - Family Member: Yeah.

Family Member: Why are they not approving the chemo? Doctor: I have no clue. They don’t have to give a reason remember? They just say denied so then we’re like we don’t understand and then you play the round robin, you know talk to that person, talk to that person, at some point it’s gonna have to be talk to the Medical Director and I’m gonna be like this ain’t complicated. I would image it has probably a lot to do with you were on a trial and now you’re not and they’re behind right. So we’re moving at real time speed… Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And stuff that they have is like always behind so you know there isn’t a – there isn’t a visit right now until right now for us to say well you’re done with that study, you’re now getting Taxotere just like a regular non-study patient and I’m sure they haven’t processes that in their head. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because they go everything by notes. So everything for you has been on, on, on – oh we’re now going to get radiation, Patient: Okay. Doctor: so they don’t have a way to read and say that what I’m saying correct. Because if it’s not in a document then it isn’t so. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And that’s a struggle for us, but I have a feeling that’s what it is. But hey this may be a blessing in disguise. You’ve got the fourth coming up, you might as well just enjoy it. We will reschedule next week. I’ll scream at a bunch of more people because what else do I have to do. Doctor: And then by then hopefully the shot will have worked out. Patient: Okay

Patient: And it’s basically a high protein low carb uh kind of a program. Doctor: Ah. Patient: And so I am processing more protein. Doctor: Yep. Patient: And I believe, I believe that protein is one of the things that can drive the creatinine up. Doctor: That is true. Patient: Okay. So how do I… Family Member: It’s being done for die- his diabetic condition. Doctor: Right. Patient: Yeah. So how do I counter that? Doctor: That’s where you have to go to a nephrologist ‘cause they’re smarter than me. Patient: Okay. (laughs) Doctor: They gotta work with the kidney and in your case it really is the kidney.

Patient: Well when would my next day? Is it monthly or is it weekly? Doctor: It’s every three weeks. Patient: It’s every three weeks. Doctor: You’ll be fine. Patient: Okay, perfect. Doctor: And we can Patient: So when I get it on the eighth in terms of my work schedule; I’m an attorney; if I have a trial like the ninth or the tenth, can I - Doctor: Sure, you’ll be fine. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You’ll be fine. Patient: Got-cha. No problem, thank you. Doctor: You’re welcome. Uhm, so if you’re going to do the eighth and I’m going to see you, D____ needs to talk to you about some medicine you’re going to take beforehand. Patient: Okay.

Patient: It was cold. It was in the, in the thirties that night, but it’s back up in the seventies now. Doctor: Well you’re also in N__t so you’re used to that? Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Do you, you have my phone information? Patient: I don’t think I have your e-mail. Doctor: Do you want it? Do you want a phone? I could use yours too. Okay? Uh, here’s my card. So my office is here. Well your phone number is in here. Just give it to me on the back of the card. Patient: It’s (gives phone number) Doctor: Okay. Patient: Thanks very much. Doctor: You’re welcome. Have a nice day.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So that’s quite frankly that’s a, it’s a clinical trial we offer, but because of a stupid loophole which I didn’t realize I can’t put you on the clinical trial because you were on the other one. (Laughs) Patient: Right. Doctor: And uhm it’s a loophole I’m going to fix. Patient: Uh hum. Patient: Right. Doctor: Can I tell you how much that’s gonna increase the fifty/fifty odds? No. Can I tell you that that’s the most aggressive thing we can do for this cancer right now anywhere in the world? Yes. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It’s what you know basically how I take care, how I try to take care of guys like you who are young and I want to hit the cancer really hard. Patient: Right. Doctor: So your choice basically is radiation with hormones or if you want to try a super sort of therapy, with chemo, super hormones, we can do that. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: - but when he have a ten… Doctor: Well and the hard part is it’s right here, it’s this pelvic pain that Dr. P___ is dealing with. Patient: No, no it wasn’t. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: It was this thing over here, whatever. Doctor: And that, I mean it’s all kind of, but it’s all here, it’s not here, Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: you know it’s not in his head, it’s here and that’s the only part that could go wrong. Family Member: So doctor he hears that it’s okay for him to be on that motorcycle? Doctor: What I’m saying is, for me, I don’t advise it. But if you say medically if there is some reason you can’t be on it, no. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So if he asks me is there a medical reason why I can’t be on it? No. Do I think it’s a good idea? Not really.

Family Member: And then, uh, and then he’s going to take it for awhile. And he’ll come down here and get -- in a month or how--how soon? Doctor: So what’s gonna happen is we’ll put the prescription in – Family Member: Yep. Doctor: They’ll let us know, and then by e-mail, we’re gonna – or in MyChart – we’re gonna know whether or not you can start it. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And then if you start it, then after two weeks – Family Member: Ahhhh. Doctor: We can get a PSA. If that PSA is higher than what we have, then R_ will sort of talk to you about coming back down to get some of this other stuff. So, we’ll be watching you behind the scenes – Family Member: Uh, huh. Doctor: To sort of figure out when’s the right time for you to come back. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Got it. Patient: So, the first thing is to, uh, see if I can come up (healthy)

Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: So that’s their new thing. They don’t need the catheter sometimes. Family Member: Oh, good, good. Doctor: You know? If you’re seventy-five, the veins aren’t so hot for it to hold for three hours, two, three hours, but I think with you it might be just fine. Family Member: Would you-? Okay. Doctor: So I think that’s one step where we could possibly save. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yes. And then, of course, you know, we do do this, and I really want you to consider, you know, donating the extra bloods as we go throughout the year because I get to follow you for this whole time anyways. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: So it’s not like you have to come back, and he’s, it’s just when you come back, when we stick you, we can get up to like ten extra tubes of blood because it’s that much we have to check. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Your immune system is really complicated.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: Right. Okay. Doctor: I mean, I think the rise is so small. We know it is just starting to breakthrough. Family Member: Mmm, hmm. Doctor: But, probably can’t definitively prove it right now on scans. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because the scans are so nonsensitive. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Even the PET scan. You know, sensitive but not that sensitive. Patient: Right. Doctor: If it’s just a small amount of cells, but it is enough of a sign for me. If you’re taking a medicine, it is supposed to make your PSA go down, and it starts rising up. That’s probably breaking through. So, we need to pile one more drug on there. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That’s all of the trials out in the U.S. are now like that. You’re trucking along with Enza, and uh-oh, it’s not working. We slap another medicine on there to see if we can help it. Family Member: Okay.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - um we have not seen cases where that is curative. That is also another type of therapy that delays the progression of the cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So so for example, if your primary goal was to delay hormone therapy for as long as possible, like if you really wanted at all cost to avoid hormone therapy - Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: - the one thing that we could consider would be referring you to a radiation oncologist that specializes in the type of radiation called stereotactic radio therapy, which is a very sort of focused - Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - razor-sharp beam of radiation that targets one particular area and doesn’t really cause scattering of the x-rays to other areas. So it spares the normal tissues. Patient: Um Doctor: And we have people at this place that do that. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Um but I don’t want you to go into that therapy believing that this is also a potentially curative therapy. I think it could definitely cure the tumor in that one lymph node that we can see.

Patient: For a couple of days. Doctor: Yeah it’s that whole universal precaution. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Double flush your toilet. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It would be better if you had some sort of bleach product in your bathroom or your kitchen. Patient: Sure. Doctor: It’s probably better you don’t share your glasses. Patient: Sure. Doctor: So common sense stuff Patient: Okay. Doctor: would be important.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - in more than ninety percent of the people, probably ninety-five, ninety-eight percent of the people, but the remissions are not permanent they’re not long-lasting. On average, they last anywhere from three to five years, that is an average. In many Patients they last longer than that and in some Patients they last less than that. Patient: See that’s that’s my concern with hormonal um as opposed to, and I guess I have to rely on you for your knowledge as far as what would be the best uh um method of treatment for me because ah the hormonal, I know, it it’s there and I know that it’s proven to do, you know, uh to slow progression. But I do know that it’s not that effective. It just prolongs it to give me like like an additional, like you said three to five years. But with that, is there any other method of uh treatment that we could look into that would do more of um eradicating the cancer, in a sense? I know the hormonal is going to be the next - that’s the next logical- Doctor: Uh hum. Patient: piece to do. But is there anything there as far as treatment that we could look at that - to sort of get rid of the cancer? Do you understand what I’m saying? I I know. Yeah. Doctor: Yeah, of course, that always should be the goal. No, there’s nothing that I, that I can think or that that I um can recommend that that will have a high chance of curing the cancer. Patient: There’s no radiation, there’s no chemo that, uh no combination of chemotherapy that - Doctor: Right. Patient: - would be able to kind of target - see the - my my biggest concern with the scans was that because this kin to prostate cancer, this metast, metasta - however it’s supposed to… Family Member: Metastasized. Doctor: Metastasized. Patient: …has metastasized to a point where that it’s still chemically – t - it hasn’t landed anywhere in layman’s terms, my words.

Patient: It, it it ain’t moved at all? Doctor: No. Patient: That’s good. Doctor: I’m very glad just like W___ that it’s not in your hip. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: You already say Dr. P___ a while ago do you remember that for your back. Patient: Yes. Yes. Doctor: Can I absolutely guarantee that the back isn’t causing the hip? No,- Patient: No. Doctor: -but you don’t technically have back pain right there in that spot that we pointed out. Patient: That is correct. Doctor: So that’s good news. Okay. Patient: But I do have back pain but it’s coming from the Provenge because they told me –
